title: Checkbox
summary: A checkbox is a form element that allows users to select one or multiple options.
preamble:
Checkboxes are commonly used in forms, settings, and filters to allow users to indicate their preferences.
The checkboxes are typically grouped with a theme label above and the possible options below.
anatomy-overview:
The checkbox (and other form controls) are divided in sections that are re-used between components. Header: Label, label support, contextual help, extended support.

*   **Body**: The checkbox.
    
*   **Footer**: Error message.
anatomy-details:
1.  Header label
    
2.  Header support text
    
3.  Contextual help
    
4.  Extended support text
    
5.  Checkbox label
    
6.  Checkbox support text

overview.title: Variants
overview.section-content:
*   **Default**
    
*   **Contained**: Coming soon Used on its own or together with other form components.

columns.title: Label
columns.content: All individual checkboxes must have a label to ensure clarity and accessibility. When checkboxes are grouped, the group must have a header label. Labels help users understand the purpose of the checkboxes, including those using assistive technologies.

columns.title: Optional field indicator
columns.content: Only use in the header label. We only ask for required information. If some fields are optional, we let users know by adding "(optional)" in brackets next to the field label. The word "(optional)" is shown in regular font weight to distinguish it from the label.

overview.title: Support text
overview.section-content: This can be used for both the header and individual checkboxes. Use this to explain how to fill in the field, for example how to count or what to include. Contained checkboxes don’t have support text for the individual checkboxes.

overview.title: Contextual help
overview.section-content:
If the label and support text are not enough to explain a field, we can use the info icon. Clicking the icon shows additional support text between the label support and the field.

*   Use a tooltip if space is limited.
    
*   Use a modal for large amounts of text.

columns.caption: Use the info icon to show more support text.

overview.title: Error message
overview.section-content: Used to indicate that a single checkbox must be checked or that a group of checkboxes has errors.

overview.title: Indeterminate state
overview.section-content: Used when a checkbox is partially selected, typically in parent-child relationships within nested checkboxes. Not available for the contained variant.

overview.title: Behaviour:
overview.section-content:
*   If some child checkboxes are selected, the parent shows the indeterminate state.
    
*   If all child checkboxes are selected, the parent appears selected.
    
*   Selecting a parent checkbox (whether unselected or in the indeterminate state) selects all child checkboxes.
    
*   Deselecting the parent checkbox deselects all child checkboxes.

columns.caption: The checkbox 'All' showing the indeterminate state.

overview.title: Alignment
overview.section-content:
Checkboxes can be aligned horizontal or vertical.

*   **Vertical**: This is the default alignment. It's easier to read and scan the available options.
    
*   **Horizontal**: Only used for a small set of options if the page shouldn't be to long, but try to avoid.

overview.title: Don't
overview.section-content:
*   Don’t overwhelm users with too many checkboxes on a single page or form. If you need to show many options, use a multi-select dropdown instead.
    
*   Don’t use it to toggle things on or off, use the switch component for that.
    
*   Don’t mix default and contained versions.

ux-text.title: Labels
ux-text.section-content: Write checkbox labels so customers can easily understand what checking or leaving the box blank means. This is especially important for stand-alone checkboxes, such as accepting terms or subscribing to emails with news and offers. If there is a header label, make sure it matches the individual checkbox label, whether grouped or stand-alone. Never use checkbox if the answer is yes or no.

ux-text.title: Stand-alone checkbox
ux-text.section-content: A stand-alone checkbox should clearly indicate what happens when it’s checked or left blank. Use the “I” form. Avoid using negations as this forces users to check the box to prevent something from happening. A stand-alone checkbox should state a clear action or agreement, not ask a question.

columns.title: Do
columns.content:
English

I have read the terms and conditions, and confirm that the information i have provided is correct.
